nodes.text: Hypothetical bias (HB) in choice experiments (CEs) affects external validity and varies in prevalence, direction and magnitude across contexts and measurement choices

Method: Systematic search of Web of Science plus supplementary searches produced a core dataset of 57/58 peer-reviewed CE studies that empirically compare hypothetical versus more realistic choice data

Result: Empirical evidence across the core dataset is mixed overall but shows clear domain differences: health studies mostly find negligible HB, transport studies mostly find significant HB (often downward), consumer studies mostly find significant HB, environmental studies mixed

Evidence: Summary counts and examples - health (n≈10) mostly negligible HB; transport (n≈14) largely significant HB often with SP VoT lower than RP; consumer (n≈18) majority report upward HB in opt-in and TWTP; environment (n≈15) mixed with scale-adjusted similarity in some studies

Claim: Many SP versus RP CE comparisons reveal scale differences in error variance between data sources; after scale correction marginal rates of substitution or MWTP often align even when aggregate WTP or opt-in rates differ
Evidence: Multiple studies report scale effects as a consistent observation across domains and recommend scale-adjusted comparisons of marginal trade-offs

Claim: HB manifests more strongly in total willingness to pay (TWTP) and opt-in rates, while hypothetical and real marginal valuations (MWTP, marginal rates of substitution) can be similar subject to scale correction

Claim/Concept: The paper proposes a unified operational definition of HB for CEs: deviation in a predefined aggregate or disaggregate measure due to choice data being collected in a hypothetical setting instead of a more realistic setting
Method/Concept: Conceptual framework of five degrees of realism (Classes I-V) for benchmarks ranging from online hypothetical surveys to naturalistic revealed data to structure HB tests

Claim: Operational and empirical heterogeneity (different HB definitions, benchmarks, measures, and domains) and scarcity of true revealed-preference benchmarks hinder generalisable conclusions and meta-analysis

Claim/Conclusion: Multiple sources and mechanisms explain HB: lack of payment consequentiality (incentive incompatibility), perceived lack of policy consequentiality, social desirability/warm-glow, strategic behaviour, hot-cold empathy gaps, cognitive dissonance/choice-induced preference change, design artefacts and information/attribute salience

Claim: Potential moderating factors of HB include participant characteristics (gender, personality, familiarity), good characteristics (public vs private, moral content, desirability), stake size, payment vehicle, experimental design (within vs between subject), and inclusion of opt-out/status-quo

Claim: Mitigation strategies can reduce HB but are context dependent and imperfect; examples include incentive-aligned designs, cheap talk, certainty calibration, enhanced contextual realism (virtual reality, simulators), referencing real alternatives, and post-survey scale corrections

Conclusion: HB is an unavoidable concern in CE research but does not render CEs invalid; careful design, appropriate benchmarks across realism classes, scale adjustment, and targeted mitigation can make CEs useful for representing real-world preferences
